answers.answerText: B. Increased thickness OS and normal thickness OD
C. Increased thickness OD and normal thickness OS
answers.explanation:
This patient is presenting with pain with eye movements and reduced vision from an optic neuropathy, which is a typical presentation for optic neuritis. Approximately one-third of patients with optic neuritis have mild optic disc edema with the remainder have normal appearing optic nerves. In this case, the right eye has mild optic disc edema and the left optic nerve appears normal. Therefore, we would expect to see mild thickening of the RNFL on OCT in the right eye and the overall thickness should be normal in the left eye. This is what is seen as shown below. 

![](/content/media/n18_2.webp)

questions.text: Based on the fundus photographs, what would be expected on OCT RNFL analysis?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the fundus photographs, what would be expected on OCT GCL-IPL analysis at presentation?

answers.answerText: B. Increased thickness OS and normal thickness OD
C. Increased thickness OD and normal thickness OS

answers.explanation:
Since this is an acute presentation of optic neuritis, no significant atrophy of the retinal ganglion cells is expected at this time. Therefore, we should see a normal overall average thickness in both eyes on OCT GCL-IPL. This is shown below. There are some subtle areas of thinning that are starting to occur, as highlighted by the arrows. 

![](/content/media/n18_3.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the best next investigation for this patient?

answers.answerText: A. MRI of the brain and orbits with contrast
answers.explanation:
In patients with optic neuritis, MRI of the brain is required to assess for signs of demyelination in the brain, which may indicate a diagnosis or high risk of multiple sclerosis or other demyelinating condition such as neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder. The orbits are also usually included since the pattern of increased T2-signal and contrast enhancement helps determine the underlying cause. For example, if there is longitudinal enhancement or enhancement of the optic nerve sheath it would suggest an alternative cause such as optic neuritis related to myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG)-IgG. 

![](/content/media/n18_4.webp)

![](/content/media/n18_5.webp)

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: The patient returns 1 month after initial examination and the vision has returned to 20/20 in both eyes and Humphrey visual fields are normal, what do you expect to see on OCT RNFL and GCL-IPL analysis?

answers.explanation:
We would start to see thinning of both the GC-IPL and RNFL layers. This is demonstrated below and is a permanent marker of the optic neuritis that occurred. Due to the redundancy in the visual pathways, excellent vision can still occur in the presence of this atrophy. 

![](/content/media/n18_6.webp)

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: The patient returns 1 year after initial examination, what do you expect OCT RNFL and GCL-IPL analysis to show?

answers.answerText: A. Thinning similar to 1 month after initial examination
B. More advanced thinning in both eyes
answers.explanation:
The GC-IPL and RNFL will continue to atrophy for approximately a few months after the acute episode of optic neuritis. This is demonstrated on the OCT RNFL and GCIPL reports shown below. The patient still maintained 20/20 visual acuity and normal Humphrey 24-2 SITA-Fast visual fields at the 1 year follow-up and had no additional recurrences. 

![](/content/media/n18_7.webp)

answers.answerText: C. Recovery of the thickness to normal levels
